title: An Analysis on Why Yasuo is Hated
body:
I'm going to analyze why Yasuo has such a stigma surrounding him within League's community. I'm not going to advocate for or against nerfs. This is just to discuss why certain things are or are not problems.

First lets talk about his kit:

I want to propose that what makes him powerful and what makes him un-fun to play against are separate things. Him being powerful _does_ make him more frustrating, but not any more than any other character being powerful would make them frustrating.

Yasuo has an overloaded kit. He has two passives, and two abilities that are spamable. Now this isn't inherently the problem, as there are other champions with overloaded kits that are not as widely hated. But it does contribute to people's frustrations with him.

I think that the most frustrating thing about Yasuo is that his Wind Wall takes agency away from enemies; there is something inherently frustrating about being negated that is so different from simply being out-played. Instead of playing around the opposing ultimate, it erases it and takes away the 'cool moment' that player could have had by using their ultimate. On top of that it isn't at nearly as much of a cost to him as it can be to them. A number of ultimate abilities with much longer cooldowns than Wind Wall are projectiles that can be unmade by it.

His dash used to be a big problem, such as it's stacking damage allowing Yasuo to lvl 1 cheese his opponents, but that has been nerfed. It takes practice for Yasuo to learn how to get the most out of using his dashes, just as it takes practice to learn how to predict and play around it. That said, it is still very frustrating to play against if you can't predict it and end up missing all of your skillshots. The fact that this skill requires practice to learn how to predict may be part of the reason he is so much more of a problem in lower levels of ranked play, because those of us that are in that level of play may not have as much time to practice or learn how to play around it.

---

Now on to behavior and expectations:

I propose that Yasuo has a higher skill floor than people expect. Everybody has at some point seen a godlike Yasuo player dominating a game. IT doesn't look hard, and he's got a lot of up-front power that we expect should help him stomp games. I think that leads to people just starting out with him to expect to do well (obviously this is a mistake, but it is one that a lot of people make nonetheless). What results is a situation where the player can do poorly -> not understand why -> start looking for other reasons for the game going poorly. This isn't a problem that is unique to Yasuo, it is prevalent throughout this game and makes up a majority of the toxicity we see in game.

The other reason I think Yasuo is so hated in this community is actually confirmation bias. We are more likely to remember negative experiences than neutral ones. It used to be a survival trait from humanity's early days, something we did so that we wouldn't eat poisonous plants or go near dangerous animals a second time. After many many Yasuo games, even if they are equal parts good and bad, we are more likely to remember the toxic, selfish and childish players than the mature ones who did their job and played carefully.

I think that the combination of his kit's expected power, the frustrating parts of his kit, and common toxicity and confirmation bias cause a larger than average amount of hatred for the champion and his playerbase in this community.

I find it the easiest when I'm with {{champion:122}}  or {{champion:92}} , where if he is close to me he is the one in trouble, and I can zone him from my minions so he can't dash.


Something that I want to see is his E having an ammo system, something like 3/4/5/6/7, recharges every 6 sec and refills in base (not necessary this numbers, I  want a low number early and definitely not infinite uses at max rank), I think this would solve a part of his frustration, and wouldn't hurt as much good yasuo players as they usually dash only when necessary and look for good angles to reach their target faster, but would solve the frustrating cases like after trading and running back with half hp you see your own minion wave coming and you feel like "you little traitorous bastards" as they seem like they come to aid yasuo, not you.
My goal with these changes is having yasuo care about how often he uses his dashes and give the opponent a chance to leave yasuo immobile if he makes him use all his dashes (or yasuo wastes them).


I also like one of your ideas in having his W a health bar, but instead of being like yorick's W, that bar would show how many hits can block and be consumed if it blocks something big (and maybe not having its hp decrease the 1st 0.5 sec to reward good yasuo players for the right timing), as I find his W be the most annoying in teamfights, and it feels the worst when your ability got blocked by accident when he W to block something a few seconds ago, and all this time also making adc useless.

Thanks! I agree the dash can be really frustrating, I like your idea for an ammo system, it seems like it would add a fair amount of resource management to balance out how hyper-mobile he is in lane.

Apparently early in it's design his Wind Wall was a very brief ability that would slash an incoming projectile or ability. I would love to see something like this done with it, either reducing its current duration, or making it like a cone area ability in front of him that lasts for 0.5 to 1 second.

I think if it has been out already in the teamfight... well I agree it's frustrating, and certainly wasn't blocking what he used it for anymore, and no offense meant, but at that point it is kind of on us for firing something into it, since we could see it was there.

Agree that is on the player for firing, but after a few seconds is hard to tell how much it has left, especially in teamfights where everything seems to take so long, and there is usually the case where you need to shot the ult now or it might not be useful enough to change the teamfight anymore, ending up with "God, I hope I counted right and windwall expires".
It also has one of the weirdest hitboxes, and if its not pointed directly at you is hard to see, but it can still block abilities even if is almost parallel with the skillshot as long as it barely touched the line, It happened to me more then a few times where I try to use the counterplay of the windwall by moving around it, only to still have my skillshot blocked just because it touched the edge, making me feel stupid for even trying to move around it (while also wondering if it was blocked anyway, wouldn't have been better if it was blocked from the beginning, instead of me wasting time going around it and staying close to the danger).

So I think you're right when you talk about player behavoir, but I don't think you're right when talking about his kit. I think his Windwall is actually the least frustrating thing about Yasuo.  Now Windwall was the initial thing that brought Yasuo hate. It had the full level of frustrating that you'd expect, but in the present it isn't difficult to play around.

Now I propose that almost every other part of Yasuo's kit has something that makes that spell more frustrating to play against than Windwall. Let's start with his passive. His shield is basically a "you don't get to poke during laning phase." As a character that excells with an all-in playstyle having his passive counter a playstyle that is strong against his playstyle is inherently frustrating, and the fact that it is only half of his passive makes it twice as frustrating.

On the topic of his passive, there is the other half of it. Yasuo get's free crit chance, that is inherently frustrating. "But there's a drawback." you say? Well there is a drawback that is almost entirely removed with one item that is core to any crit based build. My proposition is that IE should interact with Yasuo's passive differently than it does with basic crit in a similar way that they made IE interact with Ashe's passive.

Now for his Q. It's a spamable spell on a manaless champion that gets extra utility when used in succession and a larger hitbox when used with another spell. Did I mention it can be used for animation cancelling making Yasuo do a lot more damage than otherwise?

I proposed his W isn't annoying and am still on that.

Now for his E. It's a spamable movement spell. Not only that but it has the Kha'zix and Tristana effect in that after being used aggresively it can also be used to escape, but unlike Kha and Trist who have to get a kill Yasuo doesn't have risk attached to it, at least in laning phase.

Now for his Ult. The only major thing I propose is annoying about it is that if he uses it on you under turret the turret won't target him until the end of it allowing him to pretty freely turret dive. "It's not like he has to hit you with something to ult you. Hur Sarcasm." Yeah he has to hit you with something he can get on a moment's notice and doesn't take and resource.

I think a good fix for the Q would be to make it an auto-attack reset, thus allowing him to use it after auto-attacks, but then putting his auto-attack on cooldown, instead of allowing him to weave auto-attacks in between casts.

I agree that the dash is too low-risk for the reward he gets from it.

But I disagree with you about the passive shield and about Wind Wall.

The shield is only partially broken, and I think it counters melee champions instead of poke champions. For poke champions, auto-attacks or low cooldown poke spells are enough to burn off the shield before laying down some real damage. I think that it hurts melees a lot more, since they can't poke it off him before he engages on them, basically giving him free damage prevention in trades with them.

The Wind Wall is frustrating because it takes away from opposing players' glory moments. Now that in itself might not be such a big deal except that then the ability has so many ways it is frustrating; it lasts forever (in terms of a teamfight), it can block ultimate abilities with much longer cooldowns than Wind Wall, costing Yasuo very little while costing the opponent so much, and it can erase abilities even if they barely touch the edge of it - making abilities that look like they should have got around it just vanish.

There are two changes I would like to see made to Yasuo. First I would like to see his crit passive adjusted so that it scaled instead of being flat. This way his power spikes from crit items early in a game would be more manageable.

I would also like to see his Wind Wall changed. There are a number of things I've thought of that might help deal with the problems I've outlined in the post above, so I'll list them out here (I'm not advocating for all of these, just raising the possibilities for others to consider).

* Make it so that it doesn't block 100% of an ability, maybe just make it so it halves the damage and cc of it.
* Make its cooldown go up if it absorbs a much longer cooldown ability.
* Give it a health bar like how Reworked Yorick's wall works.
* Make it absorb abilities up to a point (like its HP bar) and then disappear, but grant him a shield equal to some % of the effects or damage absorbed.

If you nerf the Windwall, which is a huge portion of Yasuo's power budget, he'd have to get some pretty serious compensation buffs in return to keep the change power-neutral. I don't think anyone wants to see Yasuo running around with stats like an actual bruiser.

And now to address your proposed nerfs. The first makes it into a strictly worse braum shield, the second is bad for everyone since pretty well no one can figure out when it would be off CD again and it's not like it comes up more than once per fight, and the latter two would make the windwall pop pretty much instantly during endgame fights and in the face of certain abilities. 

Ability duration and width are good tuning levers if you feel like eschewing cooldown as a possibility. Full effectiveness is necessary for an ability like this or it might as well not exist in the first place.

This is all too unnecessary and would lead Yasuo to become another Irelia/Fiora type of champion, as this would be removing a large part of his survivability.

The only nerfs his W would need, if any at all are:

* Shorten its duration, as windwall is supposed to be a reactionary spell.
* Remove/Reduce its size growth per level.

I dislike Yasuo because of how easily he stomps match ups in his favor. Mid lane, with mages that are unable to stay away from him and their own minions, without unWindWall-able CC, it's a simple matter of Q, E+Q, Windwall, E+thirdQ+auto+R on the Yasuo's part, and that's a Flash blown or a kill. Against those who can, it's a skill match up, but being able to do that just feels bullshit. And it makes you think you can do that with everyone, which makes it feel bullshit when you pull off your ult and then lose the duel afterwards.

Champions who Yas can outtrade toplane and don't have the capacity to stick to him are also fucked. But most top laners can deal with Yasuo once they get a few items, if they respect the lvl 1-2 Yasuo has.

The most telling thing about Yasuo is the simple fact that when the time comes for Urf mode, Yasuo just remains Yasuo. And he can still compete as if nothing has changed.

I'd say that more of his power should be loaded on his higher levels of Q than his R to be honest. Having tried him a couple times, connecting Q consistently is not as easy as it looks. Taking 50% off a whole team by pressing R freely thanks to your Malphite/Lee Sin though...can't say it was any feat  of skill.

What are you talking about, Yasuo is one of the worst champions you can play in URF because his bread and butter abilities aren't affected by the CDR. The overall power level is significantly higher on URF because of how spam-happy other champions become, and not admitting the disadvantage that puts him at is disingenuous at best.

Also, Yasuo's ult only does about as much damage as one of his autoattacks come late game, so it's no great shakes in that respect. lockdown and arpen is where the value lies.
